programs.name: Visitability Movement / Concrete Change
programs.outcome: Pioneered 'visitability' concept requiring zero-step entrance, wide doors, accessible bathroom on main floor. Over 60 US jurisdictions adopted some form of visitability ordinance.
programs.source: Concrete Change organization / Eleanor Smith - NEEDS VERIFICATION

programs.name: Lifetime Homes Standard
programs.outcome: Required level or gently sloping approach to entrance with no steps. Became part of building regulations requiring accessible entrances in new housing.
programs.source: UK Government Building Regulations / Habinteg - NEEDS VERIFICATION

programs.name: Norway Building Regulations (TEK17)
programs.outcome: Requires level access entrance for all new residential buildings. Universal design mandated at national level.
programs.source: Norwegian Building Authority (Direktoratet for byggkvalitet) - NEEDS VERIFICATION

statistics.claim: Only 5% of US housing stock is accessible to wheelchair users
statistics.source: Joint Center for Housing Studies, Harvard University

statistics.claim: Over 20% of Canadian population will be 65+ by 2024, increasing demand for accessible housing
Cost of adding zero-step entry during construction is minimal (<$100) vs. retrofit costs of $5,000-$10,000+

notes: IMPORTANT CAVEAT: This evidence is drawn from training knowledge without live web verification. All citations marked 'NEEDS VERIFICATION' should be independently confirmed before publication. The visitability movement and Scandinavian universal design regulations are well-documented topics, but specific statistics and dates require verification. Cold-climate specific evidence (Edmonton, northern Canada) was not found in training data - this is a gap that web search could address. Evidence strength marked 'moderate' because while zero-step entry is a recognized accessibility standard, I cannot confirm current program status or recent statistics without search access.
